values.title: Running gazebo from a non-existent directory throws exception

content.raw:
I just happened to run `gazebo` from a directory that I had deleted in another shell, and go this:

    terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem3::filesystem_error'
    what():  boost::filesystem::current_path: No such file or directory

Definitely a minor thing, but it ought to be possible to work around that.
content.html:
I just happened to run gazebo from a directory that I had deleted in another shell, and go this:

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'boost::filesystem3::filesystem_error'
what():  boost::filesystem::current_path: No such file or directory

Definitely a minor thing, but it ought to be possible to work around that.

values.title: Unsubscribing then destroying a Subscriber causes problems

content.html:
Debugging a problem in the Gazebo/ROS laser plugin led to the observation that following code (approximately boiled down to a simple case, but tested like this) is unsafe:

    gazebo::transport::SubscriberPtr sub;
    sub = gazebo_node->Subscribe("foo", &CallBack, this);
    sub->Unsubcribe();
    sub.reset();

This sequence can lead to a segmentation fault at Node.cc:198:

    return iter->second.front()->GetMsgType();

Seems like the problem is that the Subscriber destructor unconditionally calls Unsubscribe().

values.title: Lost Feature - moving objects via the GUI

content.html:
The very useful feature of moving objects via the GUI has been lost by a change made in r6083:

// \todo Renable when modifying a model is fixed. // this->modelPub->Publish(msg); gzwarn << "Model modification is currently disabled. " << "Look for this feature in Gazebo 2.0\n";

Can I request that the capability be reinstated as it makes development much easier.

values.title: ros camera plugin not publishing camera_info topic

content.raw:
Dear all,

We are migrating the REEM humanoid robot simulation (https://github.com/pal-robotics/reem_simulation) to gazebo 1.5 with ROS Fuerte and Ubuntu 12.04. We have encountered some problems with the simulation of a monocular camera. Concretely, we are using the **libgazebo_ros_camera.so** plugin to simulate the camera. The 'image' topic is correctly published. However, the **'camera_info'** topic is not published. Both topics appear are listed with 'rostopic list', but the 'camera_info' topic does not respond when doing for instance 'rostopic hz <camera_info topic name>'

Can you check if the plugin is working properly?

Thanks in advance

Jordi
content.html:
Dear all,

We are migrating the REEM humanoid robot simulation (https://github.com/pal-robotics/reem_simulation) to gazebo 1.5 with ROS Fuerte and Ubuntu 12.04. We have encountered some problems with the simulation of a monocular camera. Concretely, we are using the libgazebo_ros_camera.so plugin to simulate the camera. The 'image' topic is correctly published. However, the 'camera_info' topic is not published. Both topics appear are listed with 'rostopic list', but the 'camera_info' topic does not respond when doing for instance 'rostopic hz <camera_info topic name>'

Can you check if the plugin is working properly?

Thanks in advance

Jordi

values.title: physics doxygen api documentation error for JointPtr as a regular pointer

content.raw:
in [api doc](http://gazebosim.org/api/1.5.0/namespacegazebo_1_1physics.html#a8bb4eb551dbb3ad180e039dd1d4c2cab), it shows

~~~
typedef Joint* gazebo::physics::JointPtr
~~~

but [in reality](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/e78e78c3d37a1c035243bc3171ffa54aa6e58407/gazebo/physics/PhysicsTypes.hh?at=default#cl-88), it's

~~~
typedef boost::shared_ptr<Joint> JointPtr;
~~~
content.html:
in api doc, it shows

typedef Joint* gazebo::physics::JointPtr

but in reality, it's

typedef boost::shared_ptr<Joint> JointPtr;

values.title: Laser Ray sensor not behaving when rotated.

content.raw:
Hi, I tried to add a rotation offset in z axis, but I guess it does not take into account if I wanted to say make the sensor point either 90 degrees or 180 degrees. 

```
#!xml
  <sensor name="laser" type="ray">
      <pose>0.01 0 0.0175 0 0 1.57079633</pose>
       ...
  </sensor>

```

* verify that noisy images are appropriately different from the non-noisy images

values.title: cppcheck is not really being run

content.raw:
In code_check script, calls to ```cppcheck``` are using the *--check-config* option which ensure that all headers are reachable and other sane configurations options. The problem is that, under my tests, it is doing just that, and not executed the rule checker at all.

The fix is not as easy as remove this option, because then the cppcheck time increase reaching probably until it can starts to be measured in hours, on a modern machine. This is probably caused by recursion in headers files.

Probably a solution based on not include all headers directory and parse .cc files and .hh files could work fine.
content.html:
In code_check script, calls to cppcheck are using the --check-config option which ensure that all headers are reachable and other sane configurations options. The problem is that, under my tests, it is doing just that, and not executed the rule checker at all.

The fix is not as easy as remove this option, because then the cppcheck time increase reaching probably until it can starts to be measured in hours, on a modern machine. This is probably caused by recursion in headers files.

Probably a solution based on not include all headers directory and parse .cc files and .hh files could work fine.

values.title: Raise a flag on the command line when a closing tag in an SDF isn't found.

content.raw:
I don't know if this is expected behaviour already. If so, there's a case where it doesn't work. If it's not implemented, I think it should be. Feel free to close this if it's not appropriate.  Raising a warning when Gazebo doesn't find closing tags would be very helpful for debugging.

In an SDF, I'd forgot to close an <axis> tag. As a result, it ignored the rest of the code. I was trying to debug my plugin. Little did I know, Gazebo wasn't even parsing the plugin tag because of the missing <axis> tag.  

Example: running this SDF in Gazebo from the command line will not raise any flags, but also fails to look at the plugin code.  Note the missing </axis> tag in my_joint

```
#!xml

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.3">
    
  <world name="default">
    <!-- Ground Plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
  
   <model name="box">
   <static>false</static>
      <link name="base_link">
        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
        <inertial>
          <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1</ixx>
            <ixy>0</ixy>
            <ixz>0</ixz>
            <iyy>1</iyy>
            <iyz>0</iyz>
            <izz>1</izz>
          </inertia>
          <mass>1</mass>
     
        </inertial>

        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>

      <link name="top_link">
        <pose> 0 0 1.3 0 0 0 </pose>
        <inertial>
          <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1</ixx>
            <ixy>0</ixy>
            <ixz>0</ixz>
            <iyy>1</iyy>
            <iyz>0</iyz>
            <izz>1</izz>
          </inertia>
          <mass>1</mass>
     
        </inertial>


        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.5 .5 .5</size>
            </box>>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.5 .5 .5</size>
            </box>>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>

      <joint name="my_joint" type="revolute">
        <parent>base_link</parent>
        <child>top_link</child>
        <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        
      </joint>
      
      
      <plugin name="set_joints" filename="build/libset_joints.so"/>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

values.title: Error found by latest version of Cppcheck (1.58)

content.raw:
I'm running a more recent version of cppcheck on my mac (version 1.58, vs. 1.52 on my ubuntu precise machine), and it finds quite a few more issues with the gazebo code. Most of them are style or performance, but this one is a pointer error.

~~~
[gazebo/transport/Node.cc:289] -> [gazebo/transport/Node.cc:288]:
(error) Iterator 'liter' used after element has been erased.
~~~

[Link to Node.cc:289](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/25467575e1ebea1940f81415e43cc9e348e34ffe/gazebo/transport/Node.cc?at=default#cl-289)

values.title: Gazebo grid = tripping hazard

content.raw:
The gazebo grid overlay should not be visible to camera sensors. In the DRC worlds this creates a tripping hazard when the terrain is lower than the overlayed grid (or at least the robot thinks it does, causing it to treat the grid as obstacles it needs to step over).

If it takes too much time to do this until VRC then the grid should simply be disabled in the VRC worlds.
content.html:
The gazebo grid overlay should not be visible to camera sensors. In the DRC worlds this creates a tripping hazard when the terrain is lower than the overlayed grid (or at least the robot thinks it does, causing it to treat the grid as obstacles it needs to step over).

If it takes too much time to do this until VRC then the grid should simply be disabled in the VRC worlds.

values.title: add option to disable auto fixed-joint lumping in parser_urdf.cc

content.raw: currently, all links attached by fixed joints are lumped to the parent link.  This has some efficiency gains in ODE, but complicates things.  We need to add an option to disable this.
content.html: currently, all links attached by fixed joints are lumped to the parent link. This has some efficiency gains in ODE, but complicates things. We need to add an option to disable this.

values.title: implement implicit stiffness and damping in bullet

content.raw: Once this feature is implemented, [drcsim](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim) stack using Bullet may be more efficient / comparable to ODE in performance
content.html: Once this feature is implemented, drcsim stack using Bullet may be more efficient / comparable to ODE in performance

values.title: Current Sensor_TEST fails without a display

content.raw:
When running the test suite in a machine without a display, it can not run properly the Sensor_TEST (see [default devel 285 jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/285/consoleFull) and [default devel 284 jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64/284/consoleFull))

Error:
```
81: Error [RenderEngine.cc:608] Can't open display: 
81: Warning [RenderEngine.cc:87] Unable to create X window. Rendering will be disabled
81: Warning [ServerFixture.hh:141] ServerFixture load in 0.18 seconds, timeout after 60 seconds
81: /home/yos/code/gazebo/gazebo/sensors/Sensor_TEST.cc:158: Failure
81: Value of: sensor != NULL
81:   Actual: false
81: Expected: true
81: Error [SensorManager.cc:330] Unable to remove sensor[default::hokuyo::link::laser] because it does not exist.
```

Looks like the SensorManager is returning null pointer when trying to get the hokuyo sensor defined in the world file. This does not happen when running with a valid display.

Most obvious fix is moved it to gz_build_gui_test but I want to be sure that this is expected by design.

values.title: Joint velocities are high when the joint link is in contact and the joint is not rotating

content.raw:
When a torque is applied on a joint and the joint link is in contact with an object such that the joint is stationary, the joint velocity is non-zero and can be quite large depending on the force.

I did a simple test using the sandia hands grabbing a cylinder. I've attached a screenshot of the state of the robot. On the joints left_f0_j1 and left_f0_j2 I applied an open loop force of 1.0 Nm using joint->setForce(0, 1.0) in a model plugin.

For this test I set the damping of the fingers to 0.1 and disabled the velocity limits. The physics are done using the standard parameters.

When the finger contacts the cyclinder and is in a steady state, the angle is constant and the corresponding joint velocity should also be zero. However, the joint angles and velocities in steady state are


```
left_f0_j1
  - Angle: 0.9 rad
  - Velocity: 5 rad/s
left_f0_j2
  - Angle: 1 rad
  - Velocity: 8 rad/s

```

I've attached the graphs of the test over 6 seconds to this bug report as well.

If P(I)D control is used to control the finger angle, it can easily become unstable when the finger hits an object. Depending how the velocity limits are implemented this could also lead to instabilities.

All tests are done using the gazebo_1.5 branch.
content.html:
When a torque is applied on a joint and the joint link is in contact with an object such that the joint is stationary, the joint velocity is non-zero and can be quite large depending on the force.

I did a simple test using the sandia hands grabbing a cylinder. I've attached a screenshot of the state of the robot. On the joints left_f0_j1 and left_f0_j2 I applied an open loop force of 1.0 Nm using joint->setForce(0, 1.0) in a model plugin.

For this test I set the damping of the fingers to 0.1 and disabled the velocity limits. The physics are done using the standard parameters.

When the finger contacts the cyclinder and is in a steady state, the angle is constant and the corresponding joint velocity should also be zero. However, the joint angles and velocities in steady state are

left_f0_j1
  - Angle: 0.9 rad
  - Velocity: 5 rad/s
left_f0_j2
  - Angle: 1 rad
  - Velocity: 8 rad/s

I've attached the graphs of the test over 6 seconds to this bug report as well.

If P(I)D control is used to control the finger angle, it can easily become unstable when the finger hits an object. Depending how the velocity limits are implemented this could also lead to instabilities.

All tests are done using the gazebo_1.5 branch.

values.title: ConnectionManager sleeps for 30 ms between message updates

content.raw: In [ConnectionManager.cc:266](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8e65421ce88f07be8450c2bd76cc2f86620e369d/gazebo/transport/ConnectionManager.cc?at=default#cl-266), there is a hard-coded 30 ms sleep between updates. This limits the update rate of contact and IMU sensors to about 33 Hz. This should be a smaller sleep value, or a wait on a condition variable.
content.html: In ConnectionManager.cc:266, there is a hard-coded 30 ms sleep between updates. This limits the update rate of contact and IMU sensors to about 33 Hz. This should be a smaller sleep value, or a wait on a condition variable.

values.title: Using /tmp/gz_model.tar.gz Is not friendly for multi-user systems

content.raw:
We have had an issue where one user had previously ran Gazebo, which left a file: 
``/tmp/gz_model.tar.gz`` around. It looks like gazebo does not clean up this file after downloading a model from the web. 

This was preventing any subsequent user from downloading models from the online database, as it was failing with a permissions error. (A file already existed with that name but owned by another user) We were able to resolve this by having an administrator remove the offending file. 

I originally thought this was caused by gazebo crashing (or being shut down) while it was downloading a model, but after checking just about every one of our shared machines had a ``/tmp/gz_model.tar.gz`` I believe that it is a more commonplace problem than I originally thought. 

Please let me know if this description is unclear.
content.html:
We have had an issue where one user had previously ran Gazebo, which left a file: /tmp/gz_model.tar.gz around. It looks like gazebo does not clean up this file after downloading a model from the web.

This was preventing any subsequent user from downloading models from the online database, as it was failing with a permissions error. (A file already existed with that name but owned by another user) We were able to resolve this by having an administrator remove the offending file.

I originally thought this was caused by gazebo crashing (or being shut down) while it was downloading a model, but after checking just about every one of our shared machines had a /tmp/gz_model.tar.gz I believe that it is a more commonplace problem than I originally thought.

Please let me know if this description is unclear.

values.title: joint velocity limit causes significant jitter (as shown in Sandia Hand example)

content.raw: see [this ticket on Sandia hand](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sandia-hand/issue/3/damping-extremely-large), it turns out the limiting mechanism yields jittery joint velocity.  We should think of a better limiting mechanism.
content.html: see this ticket on Sandia hand, it turns out the limiting mechanism yields jittery joint velocity. We should think of a better limiting mechanism.

values.title: Collision system seems not work when there are joints in the model [Gazebo 1.5]

content.raw:
I am using gazebo 1.5 compiled from source, in the model attached, there are two boxes linked by a y axis revolute joint.

If I remove the joint, the boxes collide and you can see one on top of another.

With joint there is an impression of one inside another.

To reproduce: I just started gazebo, click in the insert tab and add the model.

I am not sure if it is a strange behaviour, if it is restricted to y axis revolute joints, or just an error in the model.

Thank you in advance.

values.title: Heightmap texture distortion

content.raw:
Broken up from the previous lengthy issue #572:

The other heightmap distortion ticket from last year was "resolved" I'll open a ticket to re-iterate the problem:

The texture moves with the camera which makes it look like it's ~20cm farther away than it actually is. A video demonstrating the effect of texture moving around, notice how it moves across the edges of triangles (this is using the heightmap with just one texture and no normal map): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC_1MiATQBE

A picture of the stereo point cloud of the ground in front of the robot at the same height of the robot which appears ~20cm below the actual height (red grid is at -0.2m, gray grid at 0m): http://i.imgur.com/d5IxVbb.png

values.title: Heightmap collision buggy and partially different from visuals

content.raw:
Copy pasted from issue #572:

Visual geometry and collision geometry are different at some parts of the terrain, or maybe the collision geometry is buggy. See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TXkw3nV1OR0 and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r6aH04E_F_8 for some examples. This makes walking on the heightmap even more difficult and unpredictable than it already is with all the other heightmap related bugs and problems listed above.


Problem applied to Atlas:

Atlas slips, glides, and/or falls through the heightmap when it gets close to an edge. Example of extreme slipping (or maybe small penetrations that make it slip forward): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ojSBBKH9Ne8 and an example of atlas falling through the heightmap for several centimeters: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5fKJtuXpIks

values.title: MultiRayShape misinterprets ray sensor vertical angles in term of Euler pitch angles

content.raw:
A yaw, pitch, roll (3-2-1) sequence of Euler angles is used to initialize quaternion in gazebo. Illustration is given in [1, Fig. 1].

MultiRayShape is the pysics element behind the ray sensor, which is described by horizontal and vertical min and max angles. When initializing the individual rays that represent this sensor, it is assumed that horizontal angle of the sensor ray corresponds to Euler yaw angle, and the vertical angle of the sensor ray corresponds to Euler pitch angle. While this is true for the horizintal angle, Euler pitch angle should actually be the negative vertical angle of the ray (assuming a right handed coordinate system). I.e. a positive pitch (rotation around y axis) steers the x axis (ray) downwards (negative vertical angle).

The image (PointCloud) from this sensor is upside-down.
A fix for this is simple, a negative pitch angle should be passed on line 94 of gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc (#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dae44f8efd4eddfe5d0e47f614d9b1fb0abfd3bb/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc?at=default#cl-94).

[1] http://personal.maths.surrey.ac.uk/st/T.Bridges/SLOSH/3-2-1-Eulerangles.pdf
content.html:
A yaw, pitch, roll (3-2-1) sequence of Euler angles is used to initialize quaternion in gazebo. Illustration is given in [1, Fig. 1].

MultiRayShape is the pysics element behind the ray sensor, which is described by horizontal and vertical min and max angles. When initializing the individual rays that represent this sensor, it is assumed that horizontal angle of the sensor ray corresponds to Euler yaw angle, and the vertical angle of the sensor ray corresponds to Euler pitch angle. While this is true for the horizintal angle, Euler pitch angle should actually be the negative vertical angle of the ray (assuming a right handed coordinate system). I.e. a positive pitch (rotation around y axis) steers the x axis (ray) downwards (negative vertical angle).

The image (PointCloud) from this sensor is upside-down. A fix for this is simple, a negative pitch angle should be passed on line 94 of gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc (#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dae44f8efd4eddfe5d0e47f614d9b1fb0abfd3bb/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc?at=default#cl-94).

[1] http://personal.maths.surrey.ac.uk/st/T.Bridges/SLOSH/3-2-1-Eulerangles.pdf

values.title: *ToNano() functions convert in the wrong direction

content.raw:
As [noted in a question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/2334/confusion-with-commontimesectonano/), the following functions:

* Time::SecToNano()
* Time::MilToNano()
* Time::MicToNano()

convert in the wrong direction, multiplying by, e.g., `1e-9` instead of `1e9`.
content.html:
As noted in a question, the following functions:

  • Time::SecToNano()
  • Time::MilToNano()
  • Time::MicToNano()

convert in the wrong direction, multiplying by, e.g., 1e-9 instead of 1e9.

values.title: Video export option: png image sequences

content.raw:
When making videos, it's sometimes nice to work with the uncompressed frames. In addition to ogv, mp4, and avi it would be nice to support exporting a sequence of png images. The images should be named sequentially:
~~~
cameraName_timeStamp_1.png
cameraName_timeStamp_2.png
cameraName_timeStamp_3.png
etc.
~~~
These images could optionally be put in the `~/.gazebo/pictures` folder.

cameraName_timeStamp_1.png
cameraName_timeStamp_2.png
cameraName_timeStamp_3.png
etc.

These images could optionally be put in the ~/.gazebo/pictures folder.

values.title: Offer mathematics constants in sdf syntax

content.raw:
When there is need of rotating links in model definition file (sdf), for example, in pi/4 you need to compute the value and then put it there.

If the user could use a shortcut to PI value, make model build process easier and would ensure the precision of pi value.

Maybe include some others useful constants or math functions evaluation in sdf parser.
content.html:

If the user could use a shortcut to PI value, make model build process easier and would ensure the precision of pi value.

Maybe include some others useful constants or math functions evaluation in sdf parser.

values.title: VideoEncoder: maintain aspect ratio

content.raw: The VideoEncoder added in pull request #433 uses a windows size of 1024x768, but this makes the images distorted if the window has a different aspect ratio. At a minimum, we should maintain the aspect ratio so the videos don't look distorted, and power users might want to set the image size themselves.
content.html: The VideoEncoder added in pull request #433 uses a windows size of 1024x768, but this makes the images distorted if the window has a different aspect ratio. At a minimum, we should maintain the aspect ratio so the videos don't look distorted, and power users might want to set the image size themselves.

values.title: Gazebo QTest based tests do not report duration

content.raw:
Gazebo current tests based on QTest (those in gazebo/gui/) are not reporting duration when running.

We could use the QBENCHMARK macro to get duration from QTest framework. It would be nice to find a way of making this automatic when writing tests and do not rely on the user to set up the QBENCHMARK for every test.

Once run with QBENCHMARK, the proper xslt rule should be created to transform the XML node to proper time attribute in JUNIT format ready to be parsed with jenkins.
content.html:
Gazebo current tests based on QTest (those in gazebo/gui/) are not reporting duration when running.

We could use the QBENCHMARK macro to get duration from QTest framework. It would be nice to find a way of making this automatic when writing tests and do not rely on the user to set up the QBENCHMARK for every test.

Once run with QBENCHMARK, the proper xslt rule should be created to transform the XML node to proper time attribute in JUNIT format ready to be parsed with jenkins.

values.title: Log playback: play/pause and time panel not working

content.raw: The log playback feature introduced in pull request #457 allows gazebo log files to be visualized in gzclient using `gazebo -p state.log`. Currently the pause button will pause the playback once, but will not pause again after the playback has been resumed. Additionally the time panel ceases to display updated time information after pausing and resuming. It would be useful if play/pause could be used multiple times and if the time panel had accurate information.
content.html: The log playback feature introduced in pull request #457 allows gazebo log files to be visualized in gzclient using gazebo -p state.log. Currently the pause button will pause the playback once, but will not pause again after the playback has been resumed. Additionally the time panel ceases to display updated time information after pausing and resuming. It would be useful if play/pause could be used multiple times and if the time panel had accurate information.

values.title: RubblePlugin broken in default

content.raw:
Running the rubble.world with gzclient using the default branch of gazebo leads to a an exception message:
~~~
Exception [msgs.cc:448] Invalid geometry element

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'gazebo::common::Exception'
~~~
I traced it to the rubble elements losing all their sdf data after being created. I think it is caused by the changes to SDF.cc in 36663be.

I traced it to the rubble elements losing all their sdf data after being created. I think it is caused by the changes to SDF.cc in 36663be.

values.title: Skybox clouds move much too fast if gazebo runs slower than real-time

content.raw:
I just recorded a 27 second (simulation time) bag file in the vrc task 2 world, which took me 2.5 h thanks to gazebo running with a real-time factor of ~0.01. Looking at the recorded camera images, the clouds in the sky move at a extremely high speed, which probably is related to them not being properly slowed down to move in sync with simulation time.
This can be a very serious issue when working with visual odometry algorithms, as suddenly large parts of the image seem to move very fast (when the sky is visible) .

This can be a very serious issue when working with visual odometry algorithms, as suddenly large parts of the image seem to move very fast (when the sky is visible) .

values.title: gzlog echo speed

content.raw: It took about 11 minutes to do `gzlog echo state.log > /dev/null` for a 213 MB log file (for task 3) representing about 4.5 minutes of data. It took about the same amount of time to do the filtering command in the mkqual.bash script. This will be painfully long for bigger log files. We should see if there are any ways to speed up gzlog.

values.title: ogre_gazebo.h include errors

content.raw:
Using Gazebo 1.8.0 installed from source the header file **rendering/ogre_gazebo.h** is missing the "OGRE/" path for many other headers includes. 
For example:

`#include <Ogre.h>` should be `#include <OGRE/Ogre.h>`

and the same story for:

`#include <OgreImageCodec.h>`

`#include <OgrePlugin.h>`

`#include <OgreDataStream.h>`

`#include <OgreLogManager.h>`

`#include <OgreWindowEventUtilities.h>`

`#include <RTShaderSystem/OgreRTShaderSystem.h>`

values.title: ModelDatabase only active for first regression test in multi-test file

content.raw:
The Physics.RevoluteJoint tests are failing since they are unable to download the double_pendulum_with_base model. Some debugging indicated that the ModelDatabase thread gets killed after the first test (EmptyWorldODE in this case) and the ModelDatabase::modelCache variable is cleared, so that no new models can be downloaded. I don't notice this in testing on my local machine because I have a local copy of gazebo_models in my path.

Currently `common::ModelDatabase::Instance()->Fini();` destroys the ModelDatabase thread and is called in World::Stop. Since the ModelDatabase thread is created in its constructor, it never gets recreated. Perhaps creating the thread in ModelDatabase::Init?
content.html:
The Physics.RevoluteJoint tests are failing since they are unable to download the double_pendulum_with_base model. Some debugging indicated that the ModelDatabase thread gets killed after the first test (EmptyWorldODE in this case) and the ModelDatabase::modelCache variable is cleared, so that no new models can be downloaded. I don't notice this in testing on my local machine because I have a local copy of gazebo_models in my path.

Currently common::ModelDatabase::Instance()->Fini(); destroys the ModelDatabase thread and is called in World::Stop. Since the ModelDatabase thread is created in its constructor, it never gets recreated. Perhaps creating the thread in ModelDatabase::Init?

content.html:
In my gz_build_test run last night, I saw quite a few RaySensor_TEST failures. Some debugging this morning indicated that failure was more likely when running without a display, and that the failure may be caused by clearing the Sensor plugins in Sensor::Fini. I have a release mode backtrace, which doesn't give line numbers, but it can be deduced that Sensor::Fini is a precursor to the error.

[ RUN      ] RaySensor_TEST.CreateLaser

Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

values.title: Robot foot penetrates heightmap

content.raw:
Hi,

I am testing walking on vrc task 2, and I noticed the foot could penetrate the height map, which is a serious issue for development. This is tested on drcsim 2.5, gazebo 1.7. I used the default gazebo simulation parameters, but I did changed the texture rendering. Some short pauses are added between footsteps to make symptoms more visible. 

Here are some videos, 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JJCM1J6zjIk
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hNGmeutAuec
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ra4s0gKMOvE

Thanks!
Siyuan

values.title: Models are jittery

content.raw:
I created a little test package with a simple box with an IMU sensor attached to check how the accelerations of the box look. Both the internal Gazebo `ImuSensor` as well as the `gazebo_ros_imu` give very spiky outputs. While playing around with the ODE parameters I got the accelerations down to almost 0 when I set the SOR to somewhere close to 1 or below it. For the robots, with joints I had to additionally set the CFM parameter to a small non-zero value to get to acceptable values.

I am attaching my test package which outputs both ros and gazebo messages and has three test robots, one is only a box the second one has an additional imu link with a fixed joint and the third one has on top of that three wheels connected through revolute joints.
content.html:
I created a little test package with a simple box with an IMU sensor attached to check how the accelerations of the box look. Both the internal Gazebo ImuSensor as well as the gazebo_ros_imu give very spiky outputs. While playing around with the ODE parameters I got the accelerations down to almost 0 when I set the SOR to somewhere close to 1 or below it. For the robots, with joints I had to additionally set the CFM parameter to a small non-zero value to get to acceptable values.

I am attaching my test package which outputs both ros and gazebo messages and has three test robots, one is only a box the second one has an additional imu link with a fixed joint and the third one has on top of that three wheels connected through revolute joints.

values.title: Unable to parse log file

content.raw:
Hello,
I am trying to record a log file for VRC qual_task_2. I am having problem replaying the log file /tmp/qual_task_2/state.log in gazebo with -p option, it gives me the error message "Unable to parse log file". However, if I run gazebo with the qual_task_2 arena without actually doing any control, replay works fine. As soon as I publish a message to 
"/atlas/joint_commands" the log file cannot be replayed? How are we supposed to control the robot?

values.title: When model is renamed, access to links requires extra scope

content.html:
The polaris_ranger_ev model is brought into vrc_task_1.world with the name drc_vehicle. To access links within that model requires nonintuitive extra scoping on the name, to include the model's original name, e.g.:

physics::ModelPtr vehicle = this->world->GetModel("drc_vehicle");
physics::LinkPtr chassisLink = vehicle->GetLink("polaris_ranger_ev::chassis");

I would have expected that second line to be:

physics::LinkPtr chassisLink = vehicle->GetLink("chassis");

But that doesn't work.

values.title: Naming issues with nested models

content.raw:
Some of the internal functions, such as Base::GetByName may be confused by models with nested names.

For example, the [drc_vehicle model in drcsim](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/7f07297b87f1cc7cdbfa5ac280fe00213c8f6fac/gazebo_models/environments/drc_vehicle/model.sdf?at=default) includes the [polaris_ranger_ev model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/62d626727e9ad64d69a276ba63ee4ca01f836d03/polaris_ranger_ev/model.sdf?at=default). Adding a drc_vehicle and polaris_ranger_ev model to a world causes the following error message:
~~~
Error [ContactManager.cc:238] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting
~~~

This error occurs because the contact sensor is looking for a link with scoped name `polaris_ranger_ev::chassis`. The drc_vehicle includes the polaris mode, which caused it to have a link named `polaris_ranger_ev::chassis` and scoped name `drc_vehicle::polaris_ranger_ev::chassis`. This confuses the Base::GetByName function.

A workaround is to carefully rename models when they are included in other model files.
content.html:
Some of the internal functions, such as Base::GetByName may be confused by models with nested names.

For example, the drc_vehicle model in drcsim includes the polaris_ranger_ev model. Adding a drc_vehicle and polaris_ranger_ev model to a world causes the following error message:

Error [ContactManager.cc:238] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting

This error occurs because the contact sensor is looking for a link with scoped name polaris_ranger_ev::chassis. The drc_vehicle includes the polaris mode, which caused it to have a link named polaris_ranger_ev::chassis and scoped name drc_vehicle::polaris_ranger_ev::chassis. This confuses the Base::GetByName function.

A workaround is to carefully rename models when they are included in other model files.

values.title: SkyX moon manager clips gpu laser readings
Gazebo server crashing at fixed runtime with camera and create (or turtlebot)

content.raw:
Hello,
I'm testing Gazebo1.8 in a virtual machine on a non-Amazon Cloud.
I am using xvfb to provide a virtual framebuffer.

I've noticed that with the Turtlebot model (from the database) or the combination of the create and a camera that the program segfaults after 11472.50 +/- 0.1 (simulation time) seconds every time (3.2 sim hours). 

This is observed via piping gzstats to file, so there is some loss of precision. 
There is very little change in the time to failure between the following two VM types:

I've commented out the camera and seen things run for 108 hours before I terminated the run. I'm currently testing with the create commented out. Surprisingly, the simulator has been running for more than 3.2 simulated hours so far.

content.html:
Hello, I'm testing Gazebo1.8 in a virtual machine on a non-Amazon Cloud. I am using xvfb to provide a virtual framebuffer.

I've noticed that with the Turtlebot model (from the database) or the combination of the create and a camera that the program segfaults after 11472.50 +/- 0.1 (simulation time) seconds every time (3.2 sim hours).

This is observed via piping gzstats to file, so there is some loss of precision. There is very little change in the time to failure between the following two VM types:

  • m2.medium (4vcpu, 4G Ram)
  • m1.xlarge (8vcpu, 16G Ram)

I've commented out the camera and seen things run for 108 hours before I terminated the run. I'm currently testing with the create commented out. Surprisingly, the simulator has been running for more than 3.2 simulated hours so far.

I'm assuming that someone else has tested a robot with a camera and did not experience this time limit?

See the world file below.

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.3">
  <world name="default">
    <physics type="ode">
      <gravity>0 0 9.8</gravity>
      <ode>
        <solver>
          <type>quick</type>
          <dt>0.001</dt>
          <iters>40</iters>

          <contact_surface_layer>0.0</contact_surface_layer>

      </ode>
    </physics>
    <!-- A global light source -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
    <include>
      <uri>model://create</uri>
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>

    <include>
      <uri>model://camera</uri>
      <pose>0 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

values.title: Feet drift when standing due commit #1565dbd

content.raw:
Since the latests updates the feet of the robot started drifting on the ground. When standing, we can clearly see the feet moving. The easiest to measure is feet rotation, here is the data from the hip Z:

```
hip Z torque: -0.001 Nm
hip Z velocity: 0.009 rad/s
```

We tracked this down to commit #1565dbd, merge of [#494](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/494/implement-per-collision-max-contacts-param/diff)

values.title: No FNR switch in default polaris model

content.raw:
In the latest version of DRCSim, DRCVehiclePlugin looks for the FNR switch in the polaris model SDF which currently only exists in the model version in [gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models) and not in the SDF downloaded by default to ~/.gazebo/models. This causes an exception in DRCVehiclePlugin and an error in DRCVehicleROSPlugin which prevents the /drc_vehicle rostopics from being published.

I am posting the bug here instead of under drcsim because updating the model seems better than downgrading the plugin.
content.html:
In the latest version of DRCSim, DRCVehiclePlugin looks for the FNR switch in the polaris model SDF which currently only exists in the model version in gazebo_models and not in the SDF downloaded by default to ~/.gazebo/models. This causes an exception in DRCVehiclePlugin and an error in DRCVehicleROSPlugin which prevents the /drc_vehicle rostopics from being published.

I am posting the bug here instead of under drcsim because updating the model seems better than downgrading the plugin.

values.title: GPU based sensor update rates:  throttled by slowest active sensor

content.raw:
Simultaneously subscribing to 2 or more GPU based sensosrs, e.g.

    rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan

and

    rostopic hz rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw

will eventually bring both sensor update rates down to the slowest of the group (sometimes it takes a minute or so for them to synchronize).  Test on SL machine also shows both laser and camera ends up at 30Hz if listening to both streams.

Maybe a `SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop` synchronization based bug since reducing camera pixel size does not help.
content.html:
Simultaneously subscribing to 2 or more GPU based sensosrs, e.g.

rostopic hz /multisense_sl/laser/scan

and

rostopic hz rostopic hz /multisense_sl/camera/left/image_raw

will eventually bring both sensor update rates down to the slowest of the group (sometimes it takes a minute or so for them to synchronize). Test on SL machine also shows both laser and camera ends up at 30Hz if listening to both streams.

Maybe a SensorManager::SensorContainer::RunLoop synchronization based bug since reducing camera pixel size does not help.

values.title: gazebo master doesn't close disconnected sockets

content.raw:
The following stress testing script can cause gzserver to fail after about a minute:
~~~
while gztopic list; do date; done
~~~
gzserver eventually fails with a "Too many open files" error. This can be adjusted with a ulimit command, but the issue is that the gazebo master doesn't close it's sockets. Running a `gztopic list` several times and then `lsof | grep gz` will show numerous TCP connections in a CLOSE_WAIT state.
content.html:
The following stress testing script can cause gzserver to fail after about a minute:

while gztopic list; do date; done

gzserver eventually fails with a "Too many open files" error. This can be adjusted with a ulimit command, but the issue is that the gazebo master doesn't close it's sockets. Running a gztopic list several times and then lsof | grep gz will show numerous TCP connections in a CLOSE_WAIT state.

values.title: Command-line arguments are not passed to GUI system plugins

content.raw:
`gazebo::load()`  called without arguments in [Gui.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c2ee21e017ac/gazebo/gui/Gui.cc?at=default#cl-185), so the default values are zeros.

If it is disabled on purpose, then probably it is better to be mentioned somewhere on the Wiki.
content.html:
gazebo::load() called without arguments in Gui.cc, so the default values are zeros.

If it is disabled on purpose, then probably it is better to be mentioned somewhere on the Wiki.

values.title: Logs generated in Gazebo versions prior to 1.8 not compatiable with 1.8

content.raw:
The world section of logs generated in versions prior to 1.8 is different from 1.8 expects, leading to meshes not loading/loading incorrectly.  The simple work around I found was to generate a log while using 1.8, copy the <world name=>...</world> section and use it to replace the <world> section in the older log.  

This is purely a graphical issue, and the actual playback of the robot motions are fine.
content.html:
The world section of logs generated in versions prior to 1.8 is different from 1.8 expects, leading to meshes not loading/loading incorrectly. The simple work around I found was to generate a log while using 1.8, copy the <world name=>...</world> section and use it to replace the <world> section in the older log.

This is purely a graphical issue, and the actual playback of the robot motions are fine.

values.title: Depend tag in local model doesn't force download

content.raw:
It seems that adding a `<depend>` tag in `model.config` for a model that's found locally in `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` does not force download of the needed model from the online database.

[gazebo_models pull request #45](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/45/add-dependency-from-starting_pen-to/diff) was done to work around this problem.
content.html:
It seems that adding a <depend> tag in model.config for a model that's found locally in GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH does not force download of the needed model from the online database.

gazebo_models pull request #45 was done to work around this problem.

values.title: Model.config File URDF Tweak

content.raw: It would be nice if a new XML element was added to the model.config files used in the model database. Instead of requiring just the <sdf></sdf> tag, also include a <urdf></urdf> that can instead optionally be used if a URDF is being specified. This is a simple semantic thing, but helps clarify the confusing status of URDF in Gazebo. Note: this <urdf> tag would not require a version attribute, unlike the sdf element.
content.html: It would be nice if a new XML element was added to the model.config files used in the model database. Instead of requiring just the <sdf></sdf> tag, also include a <urdf></urdf> that can instead optionally be used if a URDF is being specified. This is a simple semantic thing, but helps clarify the confusing status of URDF in Gazebo. Note: this <urdf> tag would not require a version attribute, unlike the sdf element.

values.title: Camera deletion race condition

content.raw:
Error case:

1) Delete a model that has a camera. 

2) Link.cc:Fini() is called, which tells the SensorManager to remove the camera and also the RenderEngine to remove all the visuals.

3) When the RenderEngine processes the visual deletion, it will also remove the Ogre Camera.

4) It's then possible for the SensorManager to update, and in turn try to render a now deleted camera.

This caused a segfault in `SkyX.cpp:notifyCameraRender(Ogre::Camera *c)`. 
The short-term solution was to modify the first `if` statement in `notifyCameraRender` to include `|| !c`.

This may be a bug in Ogre. We should look at the Ogre code.
content.html:
Error case:

1) Delete a model that has a camera.

2) Link.cc:Fini() is called, which tells the SensorManager to remove the camera and also the RenderEngine to remove all the visuals.

3) When the RenderEngine processes the visual deletion, it will also remove the Ogre Camera.

4) It's then possible for the SensorManager to update, and in turn try to render a now deleted camera.

This caused a segfault in SkyX.cpp:notifyCameraRender(Ogre::Camera *c). The short-term solution was to modify the first if statement in notifyCameraRender to include || !c.

This may be a bug in Ogre. We should look at the Ogre code.

values.title: ContactManager remove filter function

content.raw:
The contact manager needs a mechanism to remove a custom filter.

All users of the custom filter should also use the removal mechanism when it's in place, such as the ContactSensor.
